channel.title: Need Help for making private server now! involving JDK and compiler
channel.description:
[b]Alright so i have JDK and a great source.. ive done every step.. the one problem is that when i double click the compiler and then it saids this:
'Javac' is not recognized as an internal or external command, operable program or batch file.
So as you can see something is wrong :( ... somebody please help me!! [/b][b][/b]

item.title: Need Help for making private server now! involving JDK and compiler
item.dc:creator: @M_And_W M And W
item.description:
@M_And_W wrote:

C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.6.0_23\bin

^go into Environment Variables (control panel, search for environment, then click environment variables) then the under the top box, click “New…” then add that, except make sure it’s your right JDK version (the _23 part of it). Name it “PATH”.

CLASSPATH=C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.6.0_23\bin

^that goes in the box under that one. Just name it “CLASSPATH” and copy/paste that into it.

Read full topic
item.source: Need Help for making private server now! involving JDK and compiler

item.title: Need Help for making private server now! involving JDK and compiler
item.dc:creator: @Liquid_Magic Liquid Magic
item.description:
@Liquid_Magic wrote:

You need to set your environmental variables because it’s not finding the command “java” or “javac” on it’s own. The Soul made a tutorial regarding this, and if you’d look around a bit more, you wouldn’t have had to post this…

Setting up your Environmental Variables


Environmental variables are what allows you to run your server with Java, without it you would simple get 'The path is not yet specified' so this is an extremely important step. We will firstly open 'My Computer' and click 'View System Information'. As you do this, a small applet displaying several tabs, and you will select the one that says 'Advanced' and at the bottom, click 'Environmental Variables'. Now what you're going to do, is go to your 'Path' and 'Classpath' variables and edit them.

In your Classpath variable, you're going to take everything currently inside it and edit it with your latest version of JDK, so right now it would be;

Code: [Select]
CLASSPATH=C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.6.0_11\bin;%CLASSPATH%;

Though if a newer version comes out, you would change the 'jdk1.6.0_11' to the newest version.


After you have done the Classpath variable, you're going to find the Path variable and add the code below inside it.

Code: [Select]
C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.6.0_11\bin;

The same goes for Path, if you download a newer version of JDK then you're going to change the 'jdk1.6.0_11' to your current version.

the thread is here
edit: make sure the javac command is all lowercase

Read full topic
